name: Gaucho Parrilla Argentina
highlights: I realized this was my golden opportunity to try it, so after riding down a sketchy alleyway and parking my bike, in I walked.
In particular my favorite sandwiches are the carne and the rosemary braised beef varieties.
4.5 stars rounded up because the steak sandwich and the humita are truly remarkable.

name: Banh Mi & Ti
highlights: The ambiance is clean and modern, the item names are cute and concisely described, and there are appropriate vegan options.
The viet special is my clear favorite - and the most classic choice - although everything I've had has been excellent.
the banh mi and rice bowls and bubble tea are incredible -- it's my new fav spot!

name: Burgh’ers
highlights: They even have a vegan burger for all those hippies who live in Lawrenceville that regret being vegan and need a good burger tasting fill!
The smell from the rosemary fries is amazing, and the bagel dogs could be a meal by themselves.
Got the Maggie's farm burger which came with rum aioli, chilies, caramelized onions, and smoked gouda.

name: Smallman Galley
highlights: Every single libation on their menu is half off during happy hour, including full bottles of wine!
Today there were four food stations to choose from, all very cool and ranged from breakfast/ brunch items to burgers and a Thai station.
While the concept of Smallman Galley is not new in some cities, it's a breathe of fresh air to the brunch scene in the Pittsburgh Strip District.

name: Altius
highlights: At $29, the Prix Fixe brunch was a little more than I usually like to spend but man oh man it was worth it.
charcuterie, sweetbreads, the duck duck goose and the pork chop entree were all stand outs.
My husband and I celebrated our first anniversary at Altius last night and I can't say enough about how perfect the experience was.

name: Butcher and the Rye
highlights: Butcher and the Rye has built up fo level of loyal fanaticism normally only reserved for religious leaders and heads of state.
The pig candy is delicious and has the perfect compliments of spices and sweetness to it and is perfectly married with the pork belly.
* Servers were useful with suggestions for food, drinks, and meal planning.

name: Bakersfield Penn Ave
highlights: Bakersfield is a great option for happy hour, drinks with friends, or dinner.
The pollo rojo was divine...the chicken, spicy salsa, chipotle lime crema, and cilantro all combined for one hell of a delicious bite.
Really my only disappointment is that we weren't hungry enough to split that enormous plate of mouthwatering queso.

name: Condado Tacos
highlights: A rewards program that makes you want to go back over and over and a Happy Hour that really makes that easy.
I will say the pickled red onions and mexican chimichurri were game changers in the build your own taco challenge.
Lots of vegetarian options too - solidly beats Smoke and Bakersfield in this aspect.

name: DiAnoia’s Eatery
highlights: Haven't done a happy hour here, but plan to soon.
I believe they have take-out pizza specials Monday through Thursday and even have breakfast pizzas on their Sunday brunch menu.
Excellent new addition to this part of the Strip, which is somewhat of a food wasteland with the exception of Edgar's Tacos.

name: Noodlehead
highlights: The staff is also quite knowledgeable about celiac disease and is ready and willing to point out gluten free choices on the menu.
For something a bit more saucy, my other two favorites are the Chiang Mai Curry and the Green Curry Linguine.
It's BYOB, cash only and we suggest going early because this place gets crowded quickly.

name: Morcilla
highlights: He also carefully reviewed all of the vegetarian options for our friend.
All of the dishes were incredible but the ones that stood out the most were the jamon iberico, oxtail, octopus, and the smoked baby back ribs.
The lamb meatballs were juicy and also full of flavor, and the sumac yogurt was a fantastic pairing.

name: Proper Brick Oven & Tap Room
highlights: They have happy hour from 4-6, with $5 wines, and $1 off drafts or something.
From the Bacon candy and house made chips to the Carnivore Pizza and the Pig and Fig Pizza I did not think the meal could get any better.
We got the carnivore and it was just enough to split and we devoured the whole thing in record timing.

name: Union Standard
highlights: We ordered 2 share plates the potato bread which is phenomenal and a must order and the blue crab skillet.
For appetizers she got the Sea Scallops and I got the Smoked Potato & Goat Cheese Soup.
For the main course the Lamb shank was tender and one of the better lamb shanks I have had.

name: Point Brugge Café
highlights: I always come for brunch, and I know I should branch out and try Point Brugge for dinner, but the brunch is just sooo delicious.
Started with the crab cakes which were terrific with a dill remoulade and the macaroni and cheese which was gooey and great.
If you're in a group, get the LARGE moules frites in either the white wine shallot sauce or the red curry sauce.

name: Taiwanese Bistro Cafe 33
highlights: Some things to keep in mind, parking isn't the greatest and it's not the biggest restaurant.
Being vegetarian, I always have questions and my waitress was very familiar with the menu given that it has only be open for a little less than two months!
AFAIK they are not associated together, but either the owner or one of the operators at Cafe 33 was previously at Rose Tea.

name: Streets On Carson
highlights: I would definitely recommend this place, especially during happy hour where the value for the quality is tough to beat.
As our meals, we ordered the Pan con Chicharron (so tastey and served on such a soft roll) and the duck conflict tapioca (like nothing I've ever had before and I want to eat it again and again!).
We also had the spring rolls, arancini, and lobster crepe.

name: täkō
highlights: I see this funky dimly lit place playing notorious BIG and outside it says TAKO.
Per usual both were on point but the Street Corn with the srirachi mayo was fire!
We received chips and guac, 2 appetizers (ceviche and papa bravas), and 2 tacos (al pastor & pollo asado).

name: City Works - Pittsburgh
highlights: We had the cheese curds (happy hour special) and the duck confit nachos.
We got the duck nachos, cheese curds, and firecracker rolls.
I particularly enjoyed the duck confit nachos.

name: Pork and Beans
highlights: I was able to snag a reservation for last Saturday and it was everything I expected and more.
Get the dirty fries, the brisket the pulled pork the tri-tip - it was all so good...
We settled on loaded fries, ribs, pork belly, brisket, greens, mac & cheese, broccoli salad and the baked beans with potatoes wedges to boot.

name: Eleven
highlights: When I need to impress a visiting friend I take them to Eleven for a spectacular Sunday brunch.
Wish we were in town longer as I definitely would like to come back for happy hours and to dine on the second floor open air style.
Also, you can add a set of wine pairings to the tasting menu for (I believe) $30, which I highly recommend doing.

name: Sienna Mercato
highlights: Great Happy Hour spot and perfect before Pens, Pirates, or Steelers games.
Emporio boasts an excellent draft list, with an ever-changing list of local and distant breweries.
I cannot wait for the 2nd and 3rd floors of Sienna Mercato to open, Mezzo (pizza and wine) and Il Tetto (rooftop beer garden).

name: Umami
highlights: I think this would be a really cool place to go back for a happy hour or just drinks and small bites, but it was also perfect for a different kind of birthday dinner I knew Bobby would enjoy.
I recommend the bacon wrapped quail egg, the pork belly, the kabucha pumpkin and the meat ball skewers.
To get there find the big glossy black door on the side of round corner cantina, climb the two flights of stairs, and you're there!
address:
202 38th St
(Above Round Corner Cantina)
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15201

name: Piccolo Forno
highlights: I'm going to tell you all a secret here - Piccolo Forno has a wood fired pizza oven that was built in Italy.
Ah, I almost forgot - parking sucks if you can't get into their small lot across the street from Round Corner Cafe.
It's BYOB which is great, but it's on the small side, so expect a long wait on peak hours

name: The Summit
highlights: The menu drinks are delicious and the happy hour specials make this the kind of place you can make a pitstop to every night after work.
You can play board games and card games here, and it's open when it's nice out so it's nice and breezy.
They offer a Moscow mule on tap, and when I first heard of this I thought "that can't be good."

name: The Twisted Frenchman
highlights: There are PLENTY of signs - however they need to remedy this (this is not a Twisted Frenchman issue - just giving you a heads up about parking!)
We had potato leak soup, potato chip fois gras and steak tartare, duck, and scallops followed by chocolate (with liquid nitrogen!).
It's rare to find sturgeon on a menu, but I will definitely be keeping an eye out for it now!

name: Eddie V’s Prime Seafood
highlights: The wine list is well constructed with good selections and reasonable prices.
I made a reservation for a date night, and they went the extra mile by sprinkling rose petals on the table.
And the bananas foster desert is quite the delicious experience.

name: Kaya
highlights: At Kaya, it's more like a happy happy happy hour with strong tasty drinks and delicious munchies.
The Yucatan hot bean dip with homemade chips may be the most addictive item on the menu.
Thursday's are fried chicken night, and after seeing so many other patrons had ordered it, my dining partner couldn't resist!

name: Station
highlights: We were pleasantly surprised by their new Saturday happy hour, and treated ourselves to $6 Moscow mules.
The heirloom tomato salad was great and the crispy chicken with savory Brad pudding were standouts.
Anyway, I had the CARAMELIZED CABBAGE AND TALEGGIO RAVIOLI, which was delicious, and a really unique cocktail that had beet juice in it.

name: Pirata
highlights: The only downfall noted is there is no happy hour- would have loved to come back for drinks but maybe they will change that in the future..
The empanadas were out of this world outstanding.
For starters we got the adobo wings with their jerk seasoning and a Jamaican beef patty.

name: Hidden Harbor
highlights: Hidden Harbor is a great place for an office happy hour or a birthday celebration.
We tried the tropic thunder- excellent drink which delivered with a ton of tropical and fruity yumminess.
I didn't know what to expect with a Tiki bar, but it was super fun and not "cheesy" at all!

name: Sienna On The Square
highlights: We go here often for happy hour and it's always great.
I decided on the Bucatini with the Mozerella Stuffed meatballs and the entire dish was to DIE for.
The parmesan-stuffed meatballs oozing deliciousness, and the buccatini (tube-shaped spaghetti) were perfectly al dente.

name: The Vandal
highlights: I didn't know but they change their menu up weekly so I was surprised to see they didn't have any vegan options on the menu.
My experience of brunch at The Vandal can best be described as rich comfort food served in a delicate and bright cafe.
It was cooked perfectly, and the tomato mayo was to die for (and it comes with fries)!

name: Muddy Waters Oyster Bar
highlights: Will return to Muddy Waters to take a happy hour tasting tour of the emerald coast's oysters, or to sample their brunch offerings.
It was chefs choice so the oysters were both east coast and west coast (I apologize that I can't remember the names of them all).
Definitely recommend the hush puppies, corn bread, pierogies & fried green tomatoes!

name: Alla Famiglia
highlights: Also, don't let the neighborhood that it's in scare you, they have a safe valet parking service.
For the Third course they serve you your choice of pasta either with their famous home made vodka sauce or fettucini.
Let me end all debate and discussion - this is THE BEST VEAL CHOP YOU WILL EVER HAVE ANYWHERE.

name: Butterjoint
highlights: Happy Hour prices are a steal - $5 wines, house, but pretty good by house wine standards.
I was on fence as to what I wanted to order and he informed us that we could also order from the Legume menu.
I almost always order the Fancy Burger of the Day - they rotate depending on what ingredients are in season.

name: Cure
highlights: FYI, you can BYOB but the uncorking charge is $15.00; and parking is on the street.
The salumi was amazing, my favorite was definitely the duck spec and the pork lardo that was melt in your mouth good.
I was hoping for a duck entree, but since none were available we decided to split the squab and pork belly, and boy was I glad that we did.

name: Union Grill
highlights: It's a nice little restaurant bar with a nice beer and liquor selection which also has some nice happy hour specials.
I've never had a bad meal and I HIGHLY recommend the Burger or the Fish Sandwich with the waffle fries.
Favorites are the Fish taco, Fish Sandwich and Turkey Devonshire which was featured on Travel Channel a few years back.

name: Seviche
highlights: The only downside to Seviche is that it is on the pricier side, so try it out for happy hour first if you're not sure if you'll like it!
I had the fire and ice ceviche and cauliflower au gratin and pizco sours to drink.
The Corn and goat cheese croquettas were perfect creamy, crunchy, and delicious.

name: Piada Italian Street Food
highlights: Parking can be so difficult to find and it's not a quick in, quick out kind of place in the heart of Oakland.
Finally, we had the cannoli chips, which were a sweet delicious ending.
I decided on 3 sides-the side salad, a meatball, and parmesan stick.

name: Smoke BBQ Taqueria
highlights: They had a late night happy hour beginning at 11 pm which got us half off beers and $5 margaritas.
My go-to options are the brisket taco and the pork, but I don't really discriminate, and I've had nearly every taco on the menu.
Don't forget about the Queso with homemade pita scoops or the White Cheddar Mac, and do yourself a favor and add bacon!!

name: Spork
highlights: For both the dinner and Sunday brunch I went to, we averaged about 2 plates per person and walked out feeling full.
It's a small plates place and we tried the goat cheese and white bean spread, the vegetarian gnocchi, the scallops and lentil meatballs.
Main courses we got the following: pasta rag, scallops, mussels, and chestnut gnocchi.

name: Apteka
highlights: A lifelong carnivore,  I can honestly imagine living on Apteka's vegan dishes happily.
To top it all off, the atmosphere is tops -- hip yet casual -- and the service is friendly.
My wife and I split three different plates including a large plate of pierogis (how can you not order pierogi here?!)

name: Shiloh Grill
highlights: It was Happy Hour so I looked over their ample drink selections, including a variety of mixed drinks, wines and  their 16 beers on tap.
I'm a huge fan of Harris Grill and was pleasantly pleased to visit it's fraternal twin on top of Mt.
Also some cool things about here is they serve tater tots which you don't see very often and Tuesday night is bacon night you get free bacon!

name: Spoon
highlights: Highlights were the gorgonzola bleu cheese soufflé appetizer and spoon bar and poached pear desserts.
The muffins and chives/cream cheese scones were warm and melt-in-your-mouth delicious.
The service is amazing and the ambiance is really nice.

name: Dish Osteria and Bar
highlights: Small and full bar, perfect for happy hour after a hard day at the office.
I ordered Grigliata di Pesce which was essentially a hodge-podge of delicious seafood all brough together by polenta and eggplant.
Mine was also excellent and I loved that the noodles were cooked al dente and were a bit denser than I had been expecting.

name: Istanbul Sofra
highlights: I've seen my favorite dish (Iskender) refined and my favorite dessert (kanafeh) added to the menu.
Judging by his clean plate- he enjoyed it too :) The 4 of us then split the 4 piece Baklava.
Also they've much improved on the ambiance overall, and the outdoor seating is nice with the big umbrellas.

name: The Alcove
highlights: He also told me that breakfast items were available all day if I so chose.
I really can't say enough about how great this little gem is.
I would reccomend the Cubano or Buffalo Chicken Wrap.
address:
875 Greentree Rd
Ste 6, Bldg 4
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15220

name: Burgatory
highlights: I also enjoy their happy hour specials.
Add good service, funky-fun decor, a loaded menu, and perfect location in between Heinz Field, PNC Park, and the North Shore subway station, it's a recipe for a winner.
We are here while visiting Pittsburgh for a Pirates game.

name: Meat & Potatoes
highlights: Meat and Potatoes has officially raised the bar on what a brunch should be.
Fries pickles were delicious and the GIANT ribeye with marrow and fries was so amazing!
This fabulous destination for a meal isn't a secret so be sure to arrive hungry and call in advance!

name: The Commoner
highlights: Unfortunately, there's no happy hour but the atmosphere and drink selections make up for it.
After a wonderful 2 nights at the Hotel Monaco, the GF and I had reservations for brunch at the in-house Commoner before flying back to Philly.
For our dessert our waiter recommended the sticky toffee pudding and me & the hubby both got our own (no way I am sharing if it is that good).

name: Independent Brewing Company
highlights: I think they could go a long way to avoid that possibility if they offered more happy hour specials on food and drinks.
I got the Permanent Yard Sale by Brew Gentlemen (phenomenal) and my friend got a Manhattan.
But seriously, there's so many local breweries, this is a great option to try a good amount of them in once place!

name: The Urban Tap
highlights: Because it was still under happy hour, our table ordered and shared 4 small plates, and each was a flavorful party in my mouth.
We had brunch there & then ended up going back there Saturday night after the game; walking distance from our hotel!
We ordered carafes of the mimosas, as I'm not much of a tomato juice fan, but the bloody mary bar looked interesting.

name: Pasha Cafe Lounge
highlights: Vegetarians, don't miss the platter with zucchini and falafel - truly fantastic.
My husband had Iran to drink and I enjoyed apple tea.
I had the lamb/beef Kofte and the lentil soup.

name: Vue 412
highlights: There is a parking lot right across the street that is $10 to use, but makes it much quicker and easier than searching for street parking.
We then got tiramisu and creme brûlée for dessert which was the perfect end to our meal.
We enjoyed the Charcuterie and Fromage starter followed by crab cakes and Osso Bucco- all terrific.

name: Doce Taqueria
highlights: As a vegetarian, I personally love getting the vegan tacos and adding queso fresco on top.
not sure I'd put them above Las Palmas, but definitely a decent option for those around in South Side!
I ordered two carnita tacos on flour tortillas but you get the choice of flour or corn tortillas for every taco.

name: Carmella’s Plates & Pints
highlights: The atmosphere was described by Munch as a "pre-prohibition hunting lodge".
Ambience- stained glass windows, antique pieces throughout the restaurant and a fireplace with seating for 8 in the middle of the room.
You also get a mini appetizer (shrimp, olive, pickle and cheese) as the garnish.

name: Pallantia Tapas de España
highlights: Now I just tried Sunday brunch there for the first time and it was fantastic.
This restaurant recently relocated from Greensburg to Shadyside and is a very welcome addition to the growing culinary scene in the burgh.
Another mouth-watering tapas was the hamburger sliders with manchego , Serrano ham, Socorro aioli and chips.Both entrees were so exceptional and the paella topped the evening!

name: Cafe Du Jour
highlights: The whole menu looks fab from lunch to dinner but I had the pan seared pork chop with polenta and kale.
It's also great because it's a high end restaurant with BYOB (aka you don't spend a fortune on wine).
Reservations are also highly recommended, as the dining room is very small and intimate.

name: Sausalido
highlights: The person at our table with the gluten allergy found the waiter able to offer many choices to meet her needs.
BYOB, street parking, and be aware that they're not open some week nights - if you reserve through Open Table you should be okay.
I think we all overloaded a bit too much on the bread, bean dip, and fried gouda.

name: Penn Ave Fish Company
highlights: Parking can be a pain, but somehow I always manage to find a spot with my big truck.
We came here for late lunch they have unique payment style "honor style" eat what ever you want and pay as you leave.
I saw a guy there working on butchering a very large tuna so I know their fish is some of the freshest you can get in Pittsburgh.

name: Everyday Noodles
highlights: Along with a noodle dish (I prefer the wide noodles) I particularly love the steamed Chinese watercress with the oyster sauce (vegetarian).
The pork soup dumplings, pork vegetable wontons, and boba are still favorites to this day.
Try the Dan Dan noodles, any of the wontons/dumplings/buns, and ANY of the appetizers and you will not be disappointed.

name: Avenue B
highlights: We had no trouble getting seated but I fear that will change quickly as the word gets out about this amazing brunch.
I may have to make a special trip back to Pittsburgh just to visit Ave B.   Don't forget to bring your own wine as they are BYOB.
It's tough not to order off the wall chalkboard menu but I did get the starter pork belly lettuce wraps last time from the actual menu.

name: Legume
highlights: One thing for everyone to be cognizant about is, Legume does has Valet parking across the street which is vital in this part of Oakland.
You can enjoy a great date night at Legume and hang out at Butterjoint (restaurant bar next door) after dinner if you wish.
We had the chocolate truffle cake and it was unreal, melt-in-your-mouth chocolaty goodness.

name: Casellula
highlights: They should definitely expand to offering lunch and brunch!
Try the salt cod (Bascula?), the Polpette  ( eggplant meatball), and the Arincini (rice ball).
The blue was paired with brown Sugar fudge and the combination was lovely.

name: Whitfield
highlights: There were a wide array of food options to choose from for brunch...one of the better menus I've seen in the city actually.
The Parsnip Bread was wonderfully baked to a nice soft center but a slightly crispy outside.
It is the restaurant venue in the Ace Hotel PGH which was crafted out of an Old YMCA.
address:
120 S Whitfield St
The Ace Hotel
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15206

name: Revel + Roost
highlights: The happy hour specials were great and I got to try some Arsenal Hard Cider for the first time, which was amazing!
Had the shrimp gumbo too, which was off the hook good.
My favorite food is the heirloom spinach salad, artisan cheese tray and the butternut squash dumplings which are out of this world good!

name: Applewood Smoke Burger
highlights: There are a couple of popular restaurants close by, but you can still generally find street parking within a block.
It was not only juicy, but full of flavor and just a great tasting patty on par with Burgatory and BRGR if not better.
As others have mentioned, Applewood is in the back of Park Place Pub so you can get a beer from the Pub.

name: The Foundry Table & Tap
highlights: I definitely had an enjoyable experience and plan on going back soon whether that's for happy hour, dinner, or brunch.
Topping one of those with a lemon/lime, jalapeño, pork belly bite and either hot, pickled green bean or okra would really knock it out of the park!
My wife loved the grilled cheese with 3 or 4 cheeses in it.

name: Nox’s Tavern and Grille
highlights: Parking can be a slight challenge, there is a Main Street nearby but you may have to walk half a block
Inside it's a bit divey (dark and small), but it's very clean.
It's now the go-to place every Friday for take out.

name: The Abbey on Butler
highlights: The coffee shop was packed with people on their Macbooks, and the bar had a small happy hour crowd.
They have an excellent weekend brunch and I am looking forward to coming here for dinner one of these nights.
The building is an old funeral home that they converted into a bar/restaurant/coffee shop and the space is massive.

name: Jabo’s Smoque House and Saloon
highlights: I went to Jabo's this afternoon for lunch, the bar area was pretty crowded, which provided a nice ambiance.
Low and slow with a dry rub and all the fat rendered to keep everything nice and moist is what it's all about.
My boyfriend had the combo platter with ribs, chicken and brisket with potato salad and cornbread.

name: Turkish Kebab House
highlights: They have varied options for both meat lovers and vegetarians.
They do not have a double door system, so every time someone enters or leaves (in the winter season), a gush of freezing air rushes in.
I was worried going in because the awful Pizza Cono used to be in this location.

name: The Fire Side Public House
highlights: Their happy hour makes apps super affordable and easy to try all at once, if you so desire.
The 40 tap Draft list is awesome and the 8oz pour option makes it easy to try a lot of different ones.
To eat I ordered the black & yellow burger, this was the best burger I've ever had, hands down!!!

name: Park Bruges
highlights: I stopped in for brunch and was pleased to see a brunch menu with varied choices as well as a prefix option.
I've eaten mussels at some world class places and these were better than the best I've had!
Excellent moules frites and long list of belgian beers with some hard-to-find selections on draft!

name: Bar Marco
highlights: I would highly suggest an evening at Bar Marco for any occasion...romantic, casual, formal, after a show or happy hour.
No menu Monday is also so much fun when they bring in a different local chef every Monday to serve instead of their regular menu.
The patatas bravas,  which were crisp oven baked potatoes, were drizzled with an amazing smoky sauce that we all wanted to take home with us.

name: Nicky’s Thai Kitchen
highlights: There was no contamination of gluten, sugar, or meat in the dishes of the people who had dietary restrictions, which is super impressive!
For the entree I got the spicy chicken noodles- ordered an 8 on the 1-10 scale and woo-wee did that hit the spot!
I thought it took a little longer than it should for my entrée to come and used the time to take in the décor.

name: Lola Bistro
highlights: Intimate atmosphere, efficient service, convenient location and BYOB make Lola Bistro a solid dinner or brunch option.
The Russian honey cake was something pretty special, and I couldn't imagine anything better until I tried my companion's cannoli.
As others have mentioned, it's BYOB with a 5.00 cork fee and the interior can be a bit drafty whenever the front door is opened.

name: Subba
highlights: The vegetarian momos were SO tasty, and compared very favorably with the best momos I've experienced in the past.
I had never had Nepali food before, but everything we tried was delicious and extremely reasonably priced.
I shared the pan-seared Momos as an appetizer, I had the Nepali Chicken, and my boyfriend had the General Tso's chicken (he wasn't feeling as adventurous).

name: Naya Cuisine
highlights: I am gluten free and casein free and they were able to accommodate my requirements completely.
I had some Greek lamb balls and hummus for a pick-up yesterday, and I went for a complete lunch experience today.
Syrian meatballs with pomegranate sauce was delicious...also grape leaves and falafel....reasonable prices, good service...don't hesitate- GO!

name: Las Palmas
highlights: My favorites are tongue and rajas (potatoes, cream, and chiles which is a vegetarian option).
For $2, you get doubled up corn tortillas filled with any meat you want (they usually have 5 or 6 choices).
They have a toppings bar with the usual street taco fare- fresh onions, cilantro, and 6 different salsas and pico.

name: Grandview Saloon
highlights: So, when I was on an executive board that was planning a conference in Pittsburgh and we needed a cool place to take 35 life members for lunch I immediately thought of the Grandview saloon.
I lingered over another beer just after the sunset before taking the incline back down the hill.
We got the coconut chicken and the steak, and both were perfection.

name: Winghart’s Burger & Whiskey Bar
highlights: Beside regular potato buns, they have the choice of gluten-free buns or lettuce wraps on their burgers!
The shipwreck has Brie cheese, crispy bacon, caramelized onions, arugula, and white truffle aioli.
My favorite burger there, and in fact the only burger I've ever ordered lol, is the Shipwreck.

name: Joseph Tambellini Restaurant
highlights: Mark chose a cannoli - oh how I wished I could have one of my pre-gluten-issue favorite desserts...and I did!
We also got the butterscotch pound cake, which I couldn't stop eating and I don't even like sweets.
The veal chop might be the best entree in town and the seafood melissa is a wonderful and lighter dish.

name: Lot 17
highlights: I've had only one bad experience when they were understaffed during happy hour, but they were very apologetic about it.
I opted for coconut chicken tenders, and let me tell you, they were HUGE, juicy, and crispy!
Calm, cool, collected, and CRISP.

name: Oishii Bento
highlights: This clean and cheerful Korean/Japanese eatery serves solid lunch boxes efficiently at a reasonable price.
Whatever you order, I recommend getting a salad bowl, miso soup and their home-made kimchi.
It's kind of hard to find seating during busy hours because both upstairs and downstairs there isn't much seating area.

name: Scratch Food & Beverage
highlights: Since it's replacing Troy Hill's flagship restaurant, Billy's, Scratch's opening has been highly anticipated.
My husband loved his steak, it was a perfect medium rare and the fries are house cut.
Amazing dish which paired nicely with a local Belgium beer from Draai Laag.

name: Stagioni
highlights: Their brunch menu had some items that fit the "unch" part of "brunch", but we went for the stuff that puts the "br" in "brunch", since it was 10am.
I still find myself craving their Ricotta Gnocchi and cannot wait to go back!
We tried the homemade mozzarella as an appetizer - it met our expectations and the the bread was amazing.

name: Tan Lac Vien
highlights: Solid Vietnamese food with some Chinese options and a large vegan/vegetarian selection.
I would recommend eating here for any kind of Asian cuisine you're craving since their menu includes a lot of options.
The broth is so rich with flavor, the rice noodles were ala dente and the plate of bean sprouts, fresh herbs, limes, and jalapeños were awesome!

name: Spice Island Tea House
highlights: Great selection of tea (which is hard to find in a Pittsburgh restaurant) and good selection of vegetarian dishes.
Parking on Atwood will be tough, as it is everywhere in Oakland, so maybe plan on getting take out if you're not a student who lives within walking distance.
Slow cooked pork in a dark, flavorful sauce and coconut rice, it's just fantastic.

name: The Yard
highlights: I know that I'll be here again soon, especially because they have some fantastic happy hour options that I won't want to miss out on.
Although I think the prices for a grilled cheese is a bit on the expensive side, $15 for bottomless mimosas is an awesome deal.
What was had at my table was- the big che-bowski, the mac attack, the poppin' my collar, and the smack yo mamma.

name: Tessaro’s
highlights: Parking kinda sucks but if you circle the block a few times, you can find something.
This place serves up HUGE, tasty burgers with great toppings, and very yummy home fries-style potatoes to go with them.
we both had burgers and potato salad and I must say that was the best burgher I have ever had and I have tried a lot of them .

name: The Porch at Schenley
highlights: They have food, drinks, and happy hour for both drinks and food (I think their pizza is half off M-Fri after 9PM).
Once was for dinner which was great but if you have the chance to do the weekend brunch I highly recommend it.
All of the sandwiches come with either greens or crispy taters with curry ketchup -- more on that later.
address:
221 Schenley Dr
Schenley Plz
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15213

name: The Greek Gourmet
highlights: The only downside is they have essentially no seating and parking nearby can be a pain, but since my man lives a couple blocks away we just take it home.
Great variety of delicious hummus but my favorite here has to be the baked falafel..
Next time I'm in Pitt, I'll have to try some more of her delicious deliciousness.

name: The Elbow Room
highlights: Overall, I'm glad we stumbled onto this place, as their reverse happy hour is a great value.
It is located directly across from the Harris grill.
The back patio makes me feel like I'm on vacation visiting another city.

name: Luke Wholey’s Wild Alaskan Grille
highlights: I personally have hosted 3 of them now [2 for my CMU MBAs and 1 for the Pittsburgh Happy Hour Annual Party] and Jason the Manager is so helpful and easy to deal with.
So far we've had the amazing Bloody Mary's  oysters and lobster bisque fries.
The catfish bites were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside and were delicious when paired with the Thai Chili dipping sauce.

name: La Feria
highlights: It makes me sad that everyone goes to Pamela's when La Feria is right above it - I always go here for breakfast/brunch and am always extremely satisfied.
I saw Pamela's and thought oh well, if I can have breakfast for dinner, why not try breakfast for lunch.
It is one of the top few places in Pittsburgh to have a casual lunch or dinner that is guaranteed to be delicious every time.

name: Mezzo
highlights: The pizza with pepperoncinis has an excellent crust, tangy cheese, and delicious peppers.
(For those of you who don't know, Mezzo is on the 2nd floor of Sienna Mercato and the 3rd floor is the beer garden).
The mushroom risotto was phenomenal and will definitely be in my sights when I go back...

name: Cafe Raymond
highlights: I will definitely return to Cafe Raymond as we had a great Brunch meal and an all-round enjoyable experience.
I enjoyed my French Toast very much so but these Blueberry Ricotta Pancakes will change your mind about any other pancake you've ever had.
If you are down in the Strip, stop in and grab a good breakfast at Cafe Raymond, especially if you don't feel like waiting in a long line!

name: Le Mont
highlights: The reservation was for 830 we didn't get seated till 930 945 ...
With a view like that and the ornate decor, your celebrating your special occasion in style!
My husband and I dined here for our anniversary, and it exceeded my expectations.

name: Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh
highlights: There are a couple parking garages nearby, as well as metered on-street parking (which is free after 6pm.)
I've only come for college night, which is Thursdays at 9pm until 11pm with a live band that plays cover songs.
Must-try includes world famous freshly brewed biers (of course), Oktoberfest schweinshaxe, braised classic pork shank and potato pancake.

name: Pizzuvio
highlights: My friend with me had a Marinara Pizza ( no cheese ) which I thought was crazy until I tried it and then saw the wisdom there.
I also tried the arancino funghi, which is a fried ball of rice with cheese and mushrooms inside, served on a bed of marinara sauce.
I had suppli in Rome several years ago, and the suppli amatriciana that I got here wasn't quite up to that level.

name: Cop Out Pierogies
highlights: Tried Gluten Free Spinach and Feta, it was amazing and I was so glad to be able to enjoy pirogues with my friends and family.
Prices are very reasonable, ranging from $7.25 to $9.25 for the cop's dozen.
Their pierogies and haluski were to-die-for when we ate them in the store.

name: Monterey Bay Fish Grotto
highlights: Overall, a great experience from valet parking and wait services.
Not an everyday restaurant because prices are not low but for special occasions great to go.
Just a short walk up the hill, take an elevator to the top and step off into a dining room with stunning panoramic views and vaulted ceilings.

name: Pear and the Pickle, Cafe & Market
highlights: Street parking is also very easy to find, unlike in other parts of the city, which is a nice perk.
Delicious latte and their sausage, egg, cheese, and tomato is my new pick for best breakfast sandwich in the city.
Delicious sandwiches and great atmosphere - and who doesn't love Boar's Head meat!

name: Fat Heads Saloon
highlights: This place is always a good time, happy hour, dinner or late night drinks!
The giant gourmet sandwiches are called "Headwiches" and they are the stars of the show.
I started out by ordering one of their own brews, Bumbleberry, a honey blueberry ale garnished with what else but fresh, sweet blueberries.

name: Casbah
highlights: Happy hour prices make a stop at this bar one Shadyside's best options for higher end post-work cocktails.
Definitely recommend signing up for the Big Burrito birthday reward and coming here for special occasions!
My boyfriend ordered the short rib ravioli's and loved it- although he preferred my meal over his.

name: Cafe Zinho
highlights: One friend is majorly allergic to gluten and our fabulous waiter MORE than accommodated her questions and requests with patience.
The decor is beautiful and the epitome of cozy, and the waitresses are welcoming and pleasant to talk to.
AND, it's BYOB so bring a bottle and enjoy the wonderfulness that is Café Zinho.

name: Dive Bar & Grill
highlights: The appetizers were big portions and half off during happy hour, which was great.
Be sure to try the sweet potato tots with sweet cinnamon  butter and the pretzels with beer sheet.
Favorite item there so far has been the pierogie quesadilla with pretzel sticks and beer cheese as a close second.

name: Tres Rios
highlights: Hope they come up with a happy hour, because it's still hard to justify some of the crazy taco prices that have seemed to pop up in the burgh!
Prepare to stuff your face with pork belly tacos and shrimp ceviche.
To start I got a Winter Pear margarita which was too sweet for my taste and in a smaller glass than I had expected but it was tasty regardless.

name: Pusadee’s Garden
highlights: My girlfriend had the pad thai which was delicious, simple, and not heavy with spices and marinades.
The place is BYOB, which isn't a bad thing since it keeps your tab down and encourages sharing.
I got the street noodle number one last time I went (3 on the spice level because I'm a wimp) and really enjoyed it.

name: Cioppino Restaurant & Cigar Bar
highlights: Clean, free parking, very classy atmosphere, great prices for the quality of your experience.
The two husbands enjoyed their ($15 each) cigars and my closet-smoking friend got to enjoy a few cigs without freezing to death.
The crab cakes themselves were very tasty with minimal filler and worthy of 4.5 stars.

name: The Smiling Moose
highlights: 2 signature (strong) drinks, 3 sliders & a side for under $14 is a pretty cool happy hour.
Loved the upstairs area...laid back vibe, stuff to do (pool, darts, video games, live music).
There's about 4 signed photos of Sid Haig (Captain Spaulding in House of 1000 Corpses).

name: Spice Affair
highlights: This is our favorite Indian buffet to date--delicious vegetarian and meat options and the food was freshly prepared and hot.
The very reasonable prices and the fact that it is BYOB bump this restaurant up from a high 4 stars up to a well-deserved 5 stars in my opinion.
Tried Chili chicken, chicken makhni, paneer shahi korma, and kofta with garlic naan.

name: Church Brew Works
highlights: I'm not sure if we stopped by around Happy Hour or not, but our plates of pierogis, mushroom/lentil fritters, and beers were $3-$5 each!
Church Brew Works is an amazing brewery situated in a former church that has great pizza, great food, and  great beer.
The sanctuary is gorgeous, with stained glass windows, gothic architecture, and old pews scattered throughout.

name: Pizza Taglio
highlights: The selection is broken up into white and red pizzas, and you have about six different pizza choices for each.
BYOB and the atmosphere is relaxing, just like Rome where you can sit and linger and enjoy.
We also had the Greenpointer, with spicy soppresata and honey, which was a perfect combination of sweetness and heat.

name: Chaya Japanese Cuisine
highlights: As for the maki, the fish seemed quite fresh and the menu has a nice variety of cooked, vegetarian, and raw rolls.
Great for small groups, this BYOB serves some great sushi along with the fried chicken that everyone else is mentioning.
I do wish they had a liquor license, but BYOB is actually more affordable.

name: Daphne Cafe
highlights: I was with a group of meat eaters and vegetarians, and everybody liked what they ordered.
Outdoor seating, quality Gyros, and a selection of dips and desserts, what more can you ask for?
We usually get the gyro salad, which has a ton of meat- soo good.

name: Angkor Restaurant
highlights: As with Thai food in general, very easy for vegetarians to find options.
We also tried the red curry with chicken and braised short rib with some kind of pineapple coconut sauce...they were very creamy and not too sweet.
The four fresh spring rolls are healthy with a good balance of mint and basil.

name: Luke and Mike’s Frontporch
highlights: She even told us all about their wine dinners and brunch specials, so we may have to return to check these out!
We sat outside on the porch, which is beautifully decorated, surrounded by trees and flowers, and on a nice quiet street.
They used to be BYOB, but now they have a liquor license and are serving up booze.

name: Mercurio’s
highlights: Word is (that old gluten devil prevented me from sampling the pizzas) the flavors matched the beauty of the crusts and toppings.
The samoa gelato had every component of the samoa cookie and I could taste the shredded coconut.
It was very soft, almost pita like, yet it retained char from the brick oven giving it a smoky taste.

name: Ease Modern Comfort Cuisine
highlights: Parking in Regent Square can be tricky - parking on a side street is recommended.
Food was awesome especially the wings and seafood Mac and cheese.
For our entrees I had the cedar plank salmon, which was perfectly cooked and hubby had the ahi tuna, he loved it!

name: The Pub Chip Shop
highlights: I risked the snow storm for their Saturday brunch offerings on account of hunger.
My friend and I had the mushroom risotto and seafood pies, and split a side of "boxty tots."
You can order pot pies, huge donuts, sausage rolls and of course fish and chips or fish on a bun.

name: Murray Avenue Grill
highlights: I came to Murray Avenue Grill for my birthday brunch a few months ago, and I was impressed.
Come before or after a movie across the street at the Manor Theater.
Try Prantl's famous almond torte!

name: Bea Taco Town
highlights: This place has the BEST vegetarian tacos, chicken taquitos (dorados), chips, guacamole and Mexican rice.
I used to go to Las Palmas in Brookline for their tacos....
The potosinas were wrapped in corn tortillas with chicken, smothered in queso with slices of avocados, sour cream and pico de gallo.

name: Eddie Merlot’s - Pittsburgh
highlights: There is paid Valet parking out on the Liberty St. side and complimentary, validated  parking in the underground garage.
So we decided on the Louisiana sampler which came with a 7oz filet andouille sausage mashed potatoes and choice of soup and salad .
My fiance got lobster bisque and said there were huge chunks of lobster and the soup was overall perfect.

name: Cornerstone Restaurant & Bar
highlights: The freshness of the food, the delicious brunch cocktails and the lovely waitstaff will keep us coming back.
My friend enjoyed the Porky Pig and I devoured the Potato Benny, both versions of eggs benedict.
I had a pickle spice Bloody Mary which was as unique as it was bold and delicious.

name: Nadine’s
highlights: Nadine's is quickly becoming my favorite brunch place in Pittsburgh.
I remembered that Diners, DriveIns and Dives had been to a Southside place.
This was Earl's question to our friend Brad, a regular and local (you probably know him).

name: Chicken Latino
highlights: A great gluten-free option for someone with Celiac Disease.
The quarter chicken was tender, juicy and contained just the right amount of skin to make it the perfect lunch.
If you're feeling adventurous you can order the bubble gum-flavored, mountain dew-colored Inca Kola here.

name: Pints On Penn
highlights: I didnt eat but others love the half priced appetizers during happy hour.
I had the opportunity to try the city chicken sandwich (PORK for anyone who doesn't know what city chicken is)- it was definitely really yummy.
Their pierogies are easily the best I've ever had, and their fish tacos are delicious as well.

name: Kaleidoscope Café
highlights: With brunch in mind we ordered a tall glass of orange juice and promptly we had ourselves mimosas.
My girlfriend and I both then had the "Gnocchi Nirvana" which is a deep fried Gnocchi with "Soyrizo (vegetarian friendly!)"
I enjoyed almost everything about the place from the kaleidoscope décor on the inside to the food and even the fact that it was BYOB.

name: B52 Cafe
highlights: My husband and I always tend to split the Tofu Scramble as well, to satisfy our savory side.
Had the tofu scramble, avocado toast, and their iced green tea with agave.
We had the seitan shwarma, pick 3 with pita: Labneh, Fried Cauliflower (with garlic and lemon and some crazy delicious sauce), and Fried Tomatos.

name: Industry Public House
highlights: As I said, no happy hour just yet, but stay tuned - I'll certainly be returning to try the food(and more drinks!).
We were there ultimately to just get drinks, but my fiance' and I ended up sharing the blast pig burger and pot roast fries.
It's been very cold and frosty and nothing warms me up better than a smoke stack.

name: Red Oak Cafe
highlights: Just a really solid little joint with great quality ingredients, low carb and gluten free options, and a great Pittsburgh vibe.
Try the OTY, a Red Oak classic, for an amazing health snack or early morning pick up. :)
I would recommend the salmon avocado salad and chicken sriracha wrap!

name: Soba
highlights: Soba has great ambience for happy hour, too -- comfy seats and plenty of room for chatting.
I highly recommend eating the pad thai and washing that down with a fussy monk or  two.
This restaurant has been the restaurant of choice for any occasion- celebration of job, or birthdays.

name: Sushi Fuku
highlights: I can't wait to go back and wish there were one in Robinson, so I could go for lunch at work and more often for dinner.
This is the chipotle of sushi, service is quick and fun and it's a great quick dining stop.
Know what you're asking them to put in your roll.

name: Tamarind
highlights: Their lunch buffet is always well stocked and food is constantly being monitored and refilled.
They have naan, rice, curries, chutneys, a mix of meat and vegetarian dishes, and will bring out dosa to your table.
The curries:  I have tried the mutter paneer, the saag paneer, the aloo gobi among others.

name: Legends of The North Shore
highlights: Don't let the area scare you away - well worth the trip and the hassle of finding a parking space that is not restricted.
Lastly, a great BYOB with a reasonable corkage fee and policy and good stemware.
I had the spinach ravioli, and I'm still thinking about the flavors three weeks later, back home in Long Beach, CA!

name: Social House Seven
highlights: We shared the scallop Pad Thai, grilled shrimp skewers, Alaskan roll and Latin roll.
Who knew that Pop Rocks on sushi made so much sense?
I came here for lunch and was very pleasantly surprised after reading the mixed reviews, but the food we ordered was great!

name: Slice On Broadway
highlights: Slice excels in providing high quality cured meats, cheeses, vegetables, and pizza standbys like roasted red peppers and kalamata olives.
Last night I learned that during Pirates games you can actually enter the stadium via the restaurant.
The day we found it we went for lunch and then back for dinner.

name: Teppanyaki Kyoto
highlights: Right now, the restaurant is in their soft-opening phase, where they serve lunch and dinner by reservation only.
Based on Yelp reviews as well as our waiter, Teppanyaki Kyoto is known for its Okonomiyaki, which is like a cabbage pancake.
The takoyaki are little flour balls with seafood filing on the inside, crunchy on the outside but soft and warm on the inside.

name: OTB Bicycle Café
highlights: Pair that up with happy hour specials and $3 Great Lakes and Troegs bottles on certain days.
I always order The Thick (bacon, BBQ, onion rings) and my fiancé orders the Urban Velo (dipped in hot sauce).
I don't remember what my sandwich was called, but it was a veggie burger with spinach, roasted red peppers, tomato, and Sriracha-Ranch sauce.

name: Z-Best BBQ
highlights: Never had a problem with the food, a great place to pick up lunch and excellent people working there!
If you sit outside you can smell the smoker and it's incredible.
Oh did I mention rib dinner with two sides PLUS corn bread was $12.50?

name: Tram’s Kitchen
highlights: Trams had me covered with a "pho-style" vegetarian soup, which smelled and tasted very similar to its beef counterpart.
My favorite is the Saigon Soup, and their fresh spring rolls are just that- fresh and delicious!
The fresh springs rolls come in orders of 2 with a ginger sauce and you can get tofu or shrimp, both are excellent.

name: S&D Polish Deli
highlights: They had several other items I wanted to eat (the vegetarian platter) but I had to restrain myself since I would be eating dinner again in 3 hours....
Servings are quite large and totally shareable, especially stuff like the Pierogi Platter, Potato Pancakes.
Other items to try is the awesome array of pierogies  and potato pancakes - just astounding.

name: Umi
highlights: My omakase 11 course chef tasting was one of my most rememberable dining experiences in Pittsburgh.
Mr. Shu was a chef at NOBU NYC years ago and has definitely surpassed them in terms of quality and taste of his creations.
From the salmon tartar to the black cod with miso, everything is done to perfection and the quality is superb.

name: Fuel & Fuddle
highlights: Great happy hour special (4pm-6pm and unadvertised, I believe) and the appetizers were all really tasty.
My faves include the sweet potato fries, baked brie (!!!), Smashed Potato pizza, and turkey or buffalo burgers.
Go after 11pm for the half priced food and experience one of the best bar-food menus in Pittsburgh.

name: Aladdin’s Eatery
highlights: They also have great vegetarian, vegan and gluten free options.
This will definitely be added to my list of places to frequent at Waterworks.
I've had their pita pizzas, rolled pitas, stuffed pitas too but I always go back to getting the lamb plate or soup and salad.

name: Alihan’s Mediterranean Cuisine
highlights: For dessert we shared a Turkish pastry similar to baklava but with an angel hair crust.
Our starters were the Chef Borek and Hummus and I had the Iskinder Kebab for my entrée.
We needed somewhere to eat before a Pirate game and this place seemed reasonably priced.

name: Jerome Bettis’ Grille 36
highlights: Happy hour at the bar (with a few seats open just prior to a Pirates home game), cordial servers, and a ton of different food offerings (from the healthy choice to the fried grilled cheese...).
Great place to pre game a Steelers  or Bucs game, or in my case a Volbeat concert at Stage AE.
Plus, you gotta love that when you take a piss, there is a 2 way mirror while doing so.

name: El Burro
highlights: I would write love letters to these incredible tacos if I wasn't fearful of spilling salsa on them.
I'm a big fan of the shrimp burritos, but really, you can't go wrong with any of them.
Mahi Mahi tacos were perfect -- deep fried fillets on top of raw cabbage and onions, with a really nice sauce.

name: Simple Gourmet
highlights: I had the chickenberry wrap, which was huge for the price and delicious.
Everything was so fresh and delicious.I will definitely be returning to try another wonderful sandwich,wrap or salad.
The sandwiches were each delicious, and everyone was happy with their choice (Tuscan Chicken, Turkey Prov, Southwest Chicken, and the Havana).

name: The Yard Gastropub
highlights: Come in for Happy Hour or a night cap, beware of game days it gets packed quickly.
Whatever you do, it is an absolute must that you order the fries, sweet potato or normal, either way, it is a win.
I got the Mac Attack sandwich-grilled cheese stuffed with creamy Mac and cheese and it was one of the best sandwiches I ever had.

name: D’s Six Pax & Dogz
highlights: I went on a Wednesday evening post-happy hour and was surprised how super crowded it was, so it may be hard to get a table on weekend nights.
I kid you not, I've sometimes found myself in the beer cave for over 45 minutes agonizing over crafting the perfect six pack.
Archetypal, the majestic franks within each sheath of bread, but particularly the Chicago, were mountains above ballpark or arena fare.

name: Wicked Fox
highlights: Their beer prices get even better during happy hours (5-7 on weekdays) when you save $2/beer.
This is a great little bar if you love a relaxed space and good bar food.
I had the cauliflower flatbread with veggies and homemade chips.

name: Chick’n Bubbly
highlights: I got everything I wanted with the lunch deal for less than $10 (bubble tea AND chicken wings?!)
The reason i am giving it four start is they only have two sauces to chose from and no dry fried wings neither.
It's next to Oishii Bento, which has pretty decent Asian food carry out for cheap, and if you save the receipt you get 50 cents off your drink at Chick'n Bubbly.

name: Sarafino’s Pasta and Pizza
highlights: Everything we tried was delicious - mussels marianara, cheese pizza and gnocchi with the gorganzola cream sauce were the standouts.
There's only a tiny lot and some street parking, so I'm sure it would be hard to park when it gets busy.
I would definitely suggest the paying a visit and don't forget your wine as it is a BYOB.

name: The Capital Grille
highlights: Complimentary valet parking make life easier when eating downtown.
We also all shared an order of the Lobster Mac 'N' Cheese, which was one of the best side dishes I've eaten in a long time.
The only "downside" is the price but if you're saving up for a special occasion then it's worth it.

name: Grand Concourse
highlights: I still dream about their Sunday brunch, even though we moved out of state 5 years ago.
I mean not every weekend because we couldn't afford it...but for a special occasion this is the place to go!
The donut conveyer pops out fresh donuts for you that are just amazing, and you will want seconds and thirds on the bananas foster.
address:
100 West Station Square Dr
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15219

name: Girasole Restaurant
highlights: I came with my family for my graduation and they were able to accommodate my mom who has Celiac (an allergy to gluten) without any problems!
I picked the spinach and ricotta ravioli, which were large little pillows of warm goodness.
All of our dinners came with a fresh salad with sunflower seeds and a nice vinaigrette dressing and blue cheese.

name: Bluebird Kitchen
highlights: There are always vegan and gluten-free options but some great meat options too.
Frittata Sandwich and Chicken salad sandwich are just some of my favorites.
I had local fried egg + cheddar on a pretzel roll, which to my delight was HUGE and came with fresh lettuce and tomato.

name: Lidia’s
highlights: This is the place to go for brunch and they have both Saturday and Sunday brunch-hard to find in Pittsburgh.
A nice plus to Lydia's is that it also offers gluten-free options which is rare for Italian restaurants.
It is a pasta place (Atkins may roll over) and they have a favorite dish called pasta trio- three different pasta, all you can eat.

name: Kavsar Restaurant
highlights: Oh, and the for the vegetarians, there was a decent vegetarian section.
I could have had sliced beef or chicken over it but i went vegan.
We went with the eggplant roll, julien in pancake bags and finally a double order of the homemade bread.

name: Nine On Nine
highlights: This is the only place that I know of that has happy hour on Saturday night.
"I die" for Roasted Bone Marrow and I even have my teenage daughter Muff wrapped up in marrow love.
I had the pleasure of having an amazing drink served by one of the best bartenders I have ever met, Joseph.

name: Cucina Vitale
highlights: First off, there is (or at least was ) a Groupon for brunch with unlimited OJ included.
One good thing is that it's no longer cash only as Caffe Davio was, and the dinner menu looks good.
We both built our own frittatas that came with toast and home fries.

name: The Melting Pot
highlights: Parking is not an issue since there are 2 parking lot options.
We could not pass on dessert, we got the Flaming Turtle, which was milk chocolate and chopped pecans "flambéed" at our table.
They also take special requests, such as flowers, chocolate, waiting for you at the table if it's a special occasion.
address:
125 W Station Square Dr
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15219

name: Thai Cottage
highlights: A lot of the Pad Thai meat is just greasy peices of meat, but at this place, even the meat had flavour!!
I love the decor on the inside, beautiful lanterns hanging from the ceiling and benches with decorative pillows.
The flavor combination of pumpkin, sweet custard, and the coconut in the rice base was splendid.)
address:
1109 S Braddock Ave
Regent Square
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15218

name: Hog’s Head Bar & Grill
highlights: Happy hour $3 craft beers.
Pizza, fries and cheeseburgers are all very good, but my favorite was their Cajun steak hoagie.
It is such a strange and unexpected location for a restaurant I thought, but I love that type of place filled with locals and regulars.

name: P&G’s Pamela’s Diner
highlights: Easily the best brunch we've had here in our weekend trip to Pittsburgh.
I LOVE this place - as proven by convincing my parents to drive 40 mins to get breakfast here during my short visit home to PA.
First day I went with "The Morning After Breakfast Special" with some blueberry hotcakes.

name: Eden Bistro
highlights: I've been to many a vegan restaurant that does terrible, greasy vegan food the way a diner does omnivorous food.
Try the zucchini spaghetti and the beet ravioli and the recently added joloff.
If you do find yourself here for brunch, I highly recommend the Coconut, Oat and Almond Raw Cakes.

name: How Lee Chinese Food
highlights: I'm a vegetarian and ordered from the Sichuan menu.
The prices are totally reasonable for the quantity and quality of the food, and the delivery range is enormous.
The glorious physiologic reaction to Sichuan food, while your tongue is numbed out by the Sichuan peppercorns.

name: Tan Izakaya
highlights: Delicious new ramen place, and a lot of intriguing Japanese dishes on the menu, so I'll definitely be back to try more.
Quail eggs were like small breakfast sandwiches, and hot and sour soup had spicy bite with a hearty consistency.
We ordered the King oyster mushrooms, the needle mushrooms, the chicken w green onions, the pork w green onions, the beef and asparagus and the famous bacon and shrimp.

name: Randita’s Organic Vegan Cafe
highlights: I love the opportunity to eat vegan because I know it is good for me and helps me get the right nutrition.
That was to die for, the crust was delicious and the pie was great with the coconut chips on top!!
The chili is some of the best I've had and the peanut stew is great too.

name: SoHo
highlights: Lunch was reasonably priced and served up fresh anf quickly.
Probably an over-crowded zoo on Steeler game days, and probably crowded before / after Pirates games.
Then for dinner I had the turkey club and my boyfriend had the buffalo chicken wrap, all very yummy :) she even brought me a small sample of the black bean salad I was wondering about for the sides.

name: Square Cafe
highlights: There are options for everybody- lots of vegetarian, vegan, and even meat lover choices.
Perfectly cooked omelets, the most delicious hash browns, bottomless coffee in cool mugs, and friendly, attentive service!
If I feel like something sweet I get the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, light and almost crepe-like compared to the standard buttermilk.

name: Senti
highlights: The hostess made us feel welcome even though we did not have a reservation and arranged a table for us in a nice location.
We loved the tiramisu and definitely have the amaro if you enjoy after dinner drinks.
We enjoyed the lovely weather as we sat on their patio and each had such great appetizers, dinners, drinks, and desserts!

name: Joey D’s in the Park, RIDC
Shady Grove
highlights: They also have fabulous happy hour specials to take advantage of if you care for a beverage.
Tip: Wednesday is a very popular night with the Shadyside Yuppie crowd as it is half off wine bottles night (as is Friday night also).
Additionally there is outdoor seating, perfect for warm summer and cool fall days.

name: Pastitsio
highlights: They also offer vegetable, vegan, and gluten free items on the menu.
Stopped in here for a mini-hangover brunch on a Sunday a little while ago.
While the inside might do with a little added warmth, the out-door patio is pretty sweet to lounge and enjoy all the great food.

name: Tender Bar & Kitchen
highlights: Their spin on Happy Hour is called "Bankers Hours" offering 2 bucks off all cocktails 5-7, including Saturday.
This old bank converted to bar/restaurant has live music- piano player, bluegrass, they tweet what's going on.
Also as a bartender myself, I appreciate the no standing policy they have in place.

name: M&J Bistro
highlights: All in all, get all the food
We ordered calamari, corn soup, a rainbow roll, pork dumpling things...
The waitstaff is also very attentive and friendly.

name: Kiku Japanese Restaurant
highlights: Everything is extremely fresh, and if you come for lunch on a weekend there is guaranteed to be nobody there.
From the simple miso soup and house salad (which were far above others I've had) to the various platters, each dish tastes like a delicacy.
I've DONE Chaya and Sushi Too and Sushi Kim and Ginza (RIP) and Kotobuki and Ooshi Bento...
address:
225 W Station Square Dr
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15219

name: El Milagro
highlights: We also tries a vegetarian taco with fresh cilantro, peppers, and radishes.
Bistec Mexicano, enchiladas verdes and fajitas are my favorite, but i have not had a bad meal here yet in over 40 times eating here.
They let us BYOB which was nice.

name: Smiling Banana Leaf
highlights: The dish struck the perfect balance of deliciousness with the sweet Pad Thai sauce, scrumptious chicken, peanuts, and green onions.
The service was friendly, the atmosphere was cozy and quaint, and even though it's out of my neighborhood, I will be returning regularly.
I order the red curry or the pineapple or pumpkin curry (which both have the red curry as a base.)

name: Sichuan Gourmet
highlights: I think I made it about halfway through my meal before I was so full I could not continue, so I got the remainder to take home for lunch later.
So far we've tried the burger (肉夹馍), cold skin noodles (涼皮), hot oil noodles (油泼面), and minced noodles (臊子面).
The hand pulled noodles with oil sauce were superb, and the hot and spicy chicken with rice was also excellent.

name: NOLA
highlights: She was very informed as to the menu and also offered suggestions for coming back during Happy Hour.
I've been to New Orleans, so I wasn't shocked by some of the offerings since they do seem to try to keep to traditional NOLA foods.
Our favorite is the alligator tail meat appetizer that's fried & seasoned to absolute perfection.

name: Edgar Tacos Stand
highlights: The options are little meat heavy, so may be difficult for vegetarians.
You can really taste all the fresh ingredients.
I saw the Mexican hot chocolate being stirred, my eyes got wide at the sight of salsa, and the smell had me salivating.

name: Adolfo’s Restaurant
highlights: Also for brunch if you bring your own Champagne, they will provide the OJ for a small fee so you can have mimosas!!!
We finished our meal with the Tres leches, which my wife said reminded her of the dessert her grandmother used to make.
We started off with the fresh bread and the complimentary sangria, then for an appetizer had the fried plantains, which were topped with mozzarella cheese.

name: Ramen Bar
highlights: I love the Tan Tan Men, which is also available in a vegetarian version.
I used to just get the ramen ramen but I've since discovered their wontons, so I now get the wonton men in a shoyu base with an egg.
We really enjoyed the tan tan men, tenshindon rice (aka omurice, or omelet rice), and takoyaki (octopus inside a ball-shaped fried wheat batter).

name: Burgatory
highlights: The good news is, if you get there early, you get to take advantage of happy hour!
Great creative hamburger menu (they have a build your own burger menu too).
My favorite though are the incredible milk shakes and the truffle fries!

name: Thin Man Sandwich Shop
highlights: For those who may wonder if I am a vegetarian, the answer is no...but having many friends who are, I am always intrigued by those options as well.
Their namesake sandwich, The Thin Man, has Chicken Liver Mousse, Bacon, Endives and Red Wine Vinaigrette on a baguette.
I ordered The Smash (grilled chx, sprouts, goat milk) which was served on a freshly made, toasted wheat roll.

name: Onion Maiden
highlights: My favorite was the McMaiden sandwich - it was so flavorful you would never tell it was vegan.
We also loved the hot dogs (trooper, Hang Ten and Kimmy Gibbler) and the Fresh Prince Rolls.
The staff was so pleasant and attentive; the restaurant was very clean (love the gender neutral bathrooms).

name: Carmi Family Restaurant
highlights: Went to Carmi's for brunch on Sunday and the BF and I were very happy with our meals.
And all this after the make-you-wanna-slap-yo-momma chicken & dumplings soup...
I almost always get the smothered fried chicken with fried corn and mac and cheese.

name: Huszar
highlights: This restaurant also has a fairly large vegetarian menu and a full bar with some craft beer selections on tap.
Finished with the real test - sour cherry strudel and cottage cheese palacsinta.
The fried cheese in the dish was good as the outside was crispy and the inside nice and gooey.

name: Robert Wholey and Co Fish Market
highlights: Parking is tough down there and if you aren't in wholey's move your car, so their customers can park.
I'm dying to go back and try their soft-shell crab sandwich and lobster mac & cheese because of all the great things I've heard!
They have a full meat department, veggies, not as big as a Giant Eagle or a Wal-Mart, but definitely better than either place.

name: Hyde Park Prime Steakhouse
highlights: Highly, highly recommended for those looking for a jovial, affordable happy hour in a classic setting.
We really were just lookiing forward to eating creamed corn before a Steeler game for our anniversary and were compeletely blown away.
It was a good meal but Ruth Chris and Eddie Merlots are still my 1 & 2!

name: Pittsburgh Barbecue Company
highlights: Though not much for seating, this is definitely a nice spot to check out if you can squeeze over here during lunch for some takeout, or want to bring home a worthy ready-to-go picnic.
Their prices are reasonable, they were friendly and helpful the day of the event, and best of all the food was amazing.
Think of the most tasty baked apples you have ever had and you are close to what these are - amazing.

name: La Tavola Italiana
highlights: One of my favorites was the Pizza Margherita, made by fifty-year pizza biz veteran - Poppa Giaramita!
Did we mention it's BYOB and there is car parking beside the restaurant.
Byob ...which is Greta to bring friends for a relaxing nice out free of expensive rounds of drinks.

name: Little Bangkok In the Strip
highlights: No need to settle for sub-par pad thai- this place is what you would get in Thailand- at a solid restaurant.
The girls ordered Drunken Noodles and Drunken Fried Rice, both with tofu.
Tom Kar is the best coconut based soup and Little Bangkok makes it better than anyone in town.

name: La Gourmandine Bakery & Pastry Shop
highlights: The chocolate croissants are my favorite, and sometimes I treat myself to one of their glorious desserts.
Now I know the secret to happiness, and it is hidden somewhere in La Gourmandine's baguettes.
Other things I've enjoyed are Pain au chocolat ou Chocolatine, Pain de Campagne , and the Focaccia.

name: Ten Penny
highlights: Don't worry, this isn't that spot - so go on witcha bad self and impress your friend or coworker with your cool happy hour knowledge.
I highly recommend this restaurant especially if you are going to the Convention Center for any event.
We ordered the Truffled Mac 'n Cheese which is decadent and very rich.

name: Nicky’s Thai Kitchen
highlights: After trying the Pad Thai, it took me probably 5 visits to Nicky's to finally branch out and try something else on their ample, tasty menu.
With a no corkage fee (except on weekends) policy it's one of the best places for BYOB in the city.
Delicious entree of "Massaman scallops", a curry that is sweet and spicy, flavored with peanuts and coconut.

name: No. 1 Sushi Sushi
highlights: Limited seating so take out it a great idea but if you come early around 1130-1145am you can just beat the lunch rush and get a seat.
The spicy sauces drizzled on the salmon rolls added a dose of zest, and the salmon itself added some nice color and flavor.
Try the daily specials as they are excellent and the service is remarkably fast.

name: Lucca
highlights: Oakland was hopping on a Friday night so I decided to give Lucca a shot for a quick happy hour drink before heading to an event.
Service was great and the outdoor patio was the perfect dining environment.
The perfect weather and calm atmosphere definitely enhanced our experience.

name: NU Jewish Bistro
highlights: While not as diverse of a menu as Square in Regent Square, I feel the brunch is quite possible the best we have in Pittsburgh.
Any deli will serve you matzo balls and latkes, but only Nu will give you mini lake tots and "Jewish Penicillin" brisket stuffed matzo ball soup.
We ultimately went with the Reuben Knishwich and the Upstreet Dip ($12 each).

name: Fireside Caribbean Restaurant
highlights: I chose a non-spicy dish of chicken and rice, but there are spicier options available.
Well I just moved to Wilkinsburg and I thought I'd get myself something to eat after a long 12 hour day of work and man was I pleased I did.
Service isn't as good here, but they do open later and they have a bunch of Jamaican sodas and drinks.

name: Bigham Tavern
highlights: They have great happy hour specials and a lot of different drinks options (both beer and cocktails), that are changing often.
This place - as other reviewers will tell you too - used to be Kaib's.  Kaib's sauce lives on (now called BT's Original) thank the good Lord.
A few stand out flavors include: Gnarley, Honey Garlic Habanero, Hyenna, Hot Garlic, and Memphis Sweet.

name: Grant Bar
highlights: I have tried a number of things from burgers to shrimp to fish, and everything has left me feeling satisfied.
Good service, awesome turtle soup!
My dining partner had the rainbow trout which I also tasted - probably the best I've ever had.

name: The Colombian Spot
highlights: We tried Arepas, Empanadas, Bandeja Paisa, and fruit juices, and we LOVED IT!
I ordered one beef empanada as an appetizer, followed by the Steel City Arepa as my meal, with a side of sweet plantains.
Prices are reasonable so unless you have a big appetite one arepa would be sufficient.

name: Crepes Parisiennes
highlights: with a cup of coffee in a real ceramic cup, it makes for the best brunch or lunch in the city.
Their breakfast crepe with bechamel sauce is my favorite paired with a cider or a mocha parisienne (depending on the time of day).
Only cash is accepted so be prepared but there is a atm right next door.

name: Sichuan Gourmet
highlights: They have a huge selection in general, and vegetarians won't have any trouble finding a ton of great options to choose from.
The food is authentic and always brings me back to my time spent in Chengdu.
The Braised Pork Shoulder in Mild Spices* was absolutely awesome, tangy and wonderfully fatty.

name: Big Shot Bob’s House of Wings - Avalon
highlights: Not only are BSB's wings huge, but you could really never tire of their multitude of strange sauces.
The talk of beaver falls were a bit to spicy for my husband and I. We also got a solider sub.
They're crunchy, not greasy, and although the Old Bay is a little heavy handed, it's not overly spicy in a painful way.

name: Istanbul Grille
highlights: I'm drawn to any eatery with abundant vegan and vegetarian options, and this place certainly fits the bill.
The owner (Josh) is a wonderful guy - he cares more about you enjoying a satisfying meal, than taking your money for it.
I work in the Steel Tower and had never been to this place prior to them moving here.

name: Mattress Factory Café
highlights: It was honestly such a healthy and delicious brunch and the cheerful ambience of the café is also quite exquisite.
A soup/salad combo is about 5 bucks which is unheard of for a museum and anywhere really.
Enjoyed a delicious lunch with the girls at Mattress Factory Cafe.

name: Vincent’s of Green Tree
highlights: Good Italian food for those that tire of Olive Garden or Fazoli's.  In nice weather, you can dine al fresco on their deck.
There is a small bar but we opted for one of the two open tables left.
With crusts in three thicknesses, fresh ingredients, and pleasant atmosphere, Vincent's of Greentree is one of the better pizzas in the Pittsburgh area.

name: Braddock’s Pittsburgh Brasserie
highlights: the food was above average, live breakfast stations as well as all the standard hotel buffet brunch items.
The bar can hold about 25-35 people so it may not be the ideal place for group happy hour.
Braddock's is a small bar located inside the front entrance of the Renaissance Hotel.

name: Top Shabu-Shabu & Lounge
highlights: That alone makes it an excellent option for any vegetarians or vegans looking to try something new (as well as the omnivores out there, obviously).
The only thing keeping them from five stars is their lunch hot food bar in my opinion.
The sauce bar is pretty extensive and makes for a very delicious addition for dipping your meats.

name: Social
highlights: Really good drink specials, both happy hour (5-7 boasts a HUGE selection of $2 beers) and daily.
Our friend had the cauliflower patties, which we'd tried -- and loved -- at an event earlier.
I ordered a design-your-own salad and didn't really like the looks of the chicken when it arrived.

name: Triangle Bar & Grill
highlights: The neighborhood is a bit sketchy, but parking was easy and the Triangle was exactly as I remembered it, especially the orange and green tiled floor!
I had a party for my birthday on 03/22, and I got three of the battleship hoagies, the chicken salad, roast beef, and Italian.
My dad and his friend would make the drive from McDonald to Swissvale once a month for Triangle sandwiches.

name: The Carlton
highlights: They also will validate your parking at the garage in the basement of the building, so hand your ticket to the hostess.
Topping it off with some personal service, Kevin Joyce, the owner stopped at our table to see if we were enjoying or meals.
If you have a special occasion, it's worth coming here in your best outfit.
address:
500 Grant St
Bny Mellon Ctr
Pittsburgh
, 
PA
 
15219

name: Poros
highlights: Typical brunch drink options are affordable and welcome.
The charred bread that came with our hummus appetizer was particularly good, and my steak salad was so classy and on point.
The wilted greens, Chilean sea bass and baklava ice cream were the standouts of the meal although everything was delicious.

name: Walnut Grill
highlights: My daughter usually orders the Buffalo Chicken Wrap or Shaved Prime Rib Sandwich.
Monday and Tuesdays feature cheap burgers, there are drink specials daily, and the staff is always friendly.
I ordered the Salmon Balsamico with a side of sweet potatoes fries and my wife got the same thing but she got a side of vegetables and a side salad.

name: Green Pepper
highlights: Darren (came to know his name later) answered the phone and explained that karaoke is free until 10pm, but after that would cost $1.25/minute.
The Bibim bops in the main dishes and the pancake in the appetizers is a must try in mymopinion.
Recently they've included a dessert of ginger persimmon soup, which is unique and a refreshing way to end the meal.

name: La Palapa, Mexican Gourmet Kitchen
highlights: They recently won the best vegetarian soup in the most recent soup contest in Pittsburgh...this made me order one of their soups.
The restaurant is BYOB and they offered to chill the white wine we brought while we waited.
Their steelers burrito, mole, and tortilla soup is great, with reasonable price (about $11 for burrito or mole).

name: Sidelines Bar & Grill
highlights: The prices are reasonable for any time of day, however happy hour is where it's at!
The selection is broad and they also have a beer club (I don't want to brag but the bf is at the 500 level).
Wings night is on Weds but really, a dozen wings are $6.95 regularly so go anytime!

name: Cambod-Ican Kitchen
highlights: The vegetarian curry rolls were good as an appetizer, but hardly necessary as the amount of food in my dinner order was more than enough.
We asked for extra containers of moon sauce and we were told that they sell containers of it, a large one for $11...um, sold.
"It's okay to let out orgasmic moans here [because the food is so good of course].

name: Fiori’s Pizzaria
highlights: My suggestion is try their white pizza, which I think rivals the ones I've had in New York.
And I wanted to add, I noticed that a lot of the reviews take points off for the parking situation.
I always wondered how Mineo's and Aiello's in Squirrel Hill could have a competitor that I've never tasted.

name: Urban Tap
highlights: If you go during happy hour, you can make a meal out of the small plates and get drinks for a great price.
3 of us got The Benedict which had a generous portion of salmon and another person ordered shrimp and grits which she loved.
We had an order of the donut holes for the table.

name: Twelve Whiskey Barbecue
highlights: They have daily happy hour specials and the Thursday night we went it was half off apps and half off specialty cocktails and a $5 burger.
Stopped in for lunch on a Saturday, the staff is super friendly, helpful and accommodating.
The brunch burger, chicken and waffles, French toast, Belgian waffles with berries, and the big Bloody Mary!
